title: Mumtaz Score for Readmission in Cirrhosis
description: Predicts 30-day readmission risk in patients with cirrhosis following hospital discharge. This prognostic tool helps clinicians identify high-risk patients who may benefit from enhanced discharge planning, close outpatient follow-up, and preventive interventions to reduce readmission rates.

parameters.name: serum_sodium
parameters.description: Serum sodium level. Hyponatremia is associated with increased readmission risk in cirrhosis patients

parameters.name: albumin
parameters.description: Serum albumin level. Lower albumin indicates poor synthetic liver function and higher readmission risk

parameters.name: length_of_stay
parameters.description: Length of current hospital stay in days. Longer stays may indicate more severe illness

parameters.name: previous_admissions_6_months
parameters.description: Number of hospital admissions in the previous 6 months. Prior admissions are strong predictors of readmission

parameters.name: meld_score
parameters.description: Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score at discharge. Higher MELD scores indicate more severe liver disease

parameters.name: hepatic_encephalopathy
parameters.description: Presence of hepatic encephalopathy during current admission. HE increases readmission risk

parameters.name: ascites
parameters.description: Presence of ascites during current admission. Ascites complications increase readmission risk

result.name: readmission_risk
result.description: Predicted 30-day readmission probability as a percentage

ranges.interpretation: Standard discharge planning and routine outpatient follow-up may be sufficient. Consider discharge coordination with primary care provider.
Enhanced discharge planning recommended. Consider early outpatient follow-up within 7-14 days, medication reconciliation, and patient education about warning signs.
Intensive discharge planning and close follow-up required. Consider early post-discharge contact within 48-72 hours, subspecialty referrals, home health services, and transitional care programs.

Comprehensive transitional care interventions strongly recommended. Consider prolonged hospitalization if clinical status allows optimization, intensive case management, frequent outpatient monitoring, and immediate subspecialty follow-up.

references: Mumtaz K, Issak A, Porter K, Kelly S, Hanje J, Michaels AJ, et al. Validation of Risk Score in Predicting Early Readmissions in Decompensated Cirrhotic Patients: A Model Based on the Administrative Database. Hepatology. 2019;70(2):630-639. doi: 10.1002/hep.30274.

Berman K, Tandra S, Forssell K, Vuppalanchi R, Burton JR Jr, Nguyen JH, et al. Incidence and predictors of 30-day readmission among patients hospitalized for advanced liver disease. Clin Gastroenterol Hepatol. 2011;9(3):254-9. doi: 10.1016/j.cgh.2010.10.035.
Volk ML, Tocco RS, Bazick J, Rakoski MO, Lok AS. Hospital readmissions among patients with decompensated cirrhosis. Am J Gastroenterol. 2012;107(2):247-52. doi: 10.1038/ajg.2011.314.
formula: Logistic regression model incorporating age, serum sodium, albumin, length of stay, previous admissions, MELD score, hepatic encephalopathy, and ascites with specific coefficients to calculate 30-day readmission probability
notes: The Mumtaz Score was developed and validated in a large administrative database of cirrhosis patients
This score is specifically designed for patients with decompensated cirrhosis being discharged from hospital
The model showed good discrimination (C-statistic 0.68-0.72) and calibration in validation studies
Risk factors include markers of liver disease severity, complications, and healthcare utilization patterns
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and comprehensive discharge planning
May help identify patients who would benefit from transitional care interventions and close follow-up
Not intended to replace clinical assessment but rather to supplement risk stratification efforts
